In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Certainly! Below is a simple implementation of the `wrap_string` function in Julia that wraps a string at word boundaries to fit within a specified text width. The function also handles the case where the last line doesn't reach the maximum width, ensuring that it is not prematurely truncated.

```julia
function wrap_string(text::AbstractString; text_width::Int=10)
    lines = []
    current_line = ""
    for word in split(text)
        if length(current_line) + length(word) <= text_width
            # Append the word to the current line
            current_line *= " " * word
        else
            # Exceeds width, so add the current line and start a new one
            push!(lines, current_line)
            current_line = word
        end
    end
    # Append any remaining characters from the last line
    if length(current_line) > 0
        push!(lines, current_line)
    end
    return join(lines, "\n")
end

# Example usage:
text = "This is a very long string that will be wrapped into multiple lines."
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text, text_width=20)
println(wrapped_text)
```

When you run this code, you should see something like the following printed to the console:

```
This is a very long
string that will be
wrapped into multiple
lines.
```

The `wrap_string` function works by iterating over the words in the input string and appending them to a current line. If the length of the current line plus the word exceeds the specified text width, the word is added to the next line. The function also handles the case where the last line doesn't have enough words to fill the width, ensuring that it is not prematurely terminated.
